p: Soon after the emergence of CHIKV on Reunion Island, congenital transmission of CHIKV was hypothesized following reports of CHIKF in infants 2–4 days old because viremia had been shown to occur between 3–5 days following infection [ 98, 99]. Beginning in 2006, congenital and perinatal transmission of CHIKV was reported in Reunion Island ( Table 1) [ 14, 15, 16, 98]. These reports were soon followed by thorough descriptions of CHIKF in patients from a few days old up through 18 years of age [ 36, 100]. Here, most infants less than six months of age exhibited rash and dehydration while children between 3 and 18 years old did not exhibit rash, but, instead, were significantly more likely to have neurologic and digestive symptoms [ 36, 101].
